entry.title: Graph Theorem 1 - Introduction to Graphs
entry.content:
Quick Guide

  1. Graph Terminology and Notation
  2. The Handshaking Lemma
  3. Special Graphs
  4. Walks and Paths
  5. Connected Components
  6. Counting Connected Components

Graph Terminology and Notation

An undirected graph is a pair $G=(V,E)$ where $V$ is a finite non-empty set of vertices or nodes and $E\subseteq 2^V$ is a finite (possibly empty) set of edges consisting only of subset of cardinality 2 (two nodes form an edge).

We use the notation $u\mathrm{-}v$ (equivalently, $v\mathrm{-}u$ in undirected graph) for both edges {$u,v$} and to say $u$ and $v$ are linked by an edge.
So that $G$ can be represented in two ways:

$G = (\{1,2,3,4\}, \{\{1,2\}, \{1,3\}, \{2,3\}, \{2,4\}\})$


or

$$G = (\{1,2,3,4\}, \{1\mathrm{-}2, 1\mathrm{-}3, 2\mathrm{-}3, 2\mathrm{-}4\})$$


We will say that the edge $u\mathrm{-}v$ is incident to either of its endpoints $u$ and $v$.
Two vertices such that $u\mathrm{-}v$ are called adjacent(or neighbors).
Note that we now only deal with simple graphs where there are no “loops” or “parallel edges”.

The degree of a vertex, $deg(u)$, is the number of neighbors of $u$ (the number of vertices adjacent to $u$).
A vertex of degree 0 is called isolated.

The Handshaking Lemma

The sum of the degrees of all nodes in a graph is twice the number of edges, that is

$\sum_{v\in V} deg(v) = 2 |E|$

Proposition: In any graph there are an even number of vertices of odd degree.

Special Graphs

Edgeless graphs

An edgeless graph $G = (V, E)$ has some vertices but no edges. Therefore, $E = \emptyset$ hence $|E| = 0$.

Complete graphs

A complete graph on $n\geq 1$ vertices, notation $K_n$, has edges between any two vertices.
Therefore, $K_n = (V,E)$ where $|V| = n$ and $|E| = \{\{u,v\}|u,v\in V\}.$

The number of edges in $k_n$ is the number of unordered pairs $\binom{n}{2} = \frac{n(n-1)}{2}$.

Path graphs

A path graph on $n\geq 1$ vertices, notation $P_n$, has $n$ vertices and $n-1$ edges arranged “in a row”.

Note that for $n\geq3$ we have two vertices of degree 1 in $P_n$ and the rest have degree 2.

Cycle graphs

A cycle graph on $n\geq 3$ vertices, notation $C_n$, has $n$ vertices and $n$ edges arranged “in a circle”. Note that in cycle graphs all vertices have degree 2.

Grid graphs

Let $m,n\geq 1$. An $m\times n$ grid graph has $m$ rows of $n$ vertices. Each vertex is linked by an edge to the vertices “closest” to it.
Here is an example of a $3\times5$ grid graph:

Note that an $m \times n$ grid graph has $mn$ vertices. When $m,n\geq3$, we have 4 corner vertices with degree 2, and the other vertices have degree 3 or 4.

Walks and Paths

Walks

A walk is a non-empty sequence of vertices consecutively linked by edges: $u_0, u_1, \ldots, u_k$ such that $u_0\mathrm{-} u_1\mathrm{-} \ldots\mathrm{-} u_k$. This walk is form $u_0$ to $u_k$ (the endpoints of the walk) and $u_0$ and $u_k$ are connected by this walk. The length of this walk is the number $k$ of edges.

In this graph, $1\mathrm{-}2\mathrm{-}4$ is a walk of length 2.

Paths

A path is a walk in which all the vertices are distinct.
Walks of length 0 are paths.
Walks of length 1 are already paths because we cannot have loops in simple graph.
$u\mathrm{-}v\mathrm{-}u$ is a walk of length 2 but not a path. For example, $3\mathrm{-}2\mathrm{-}4$ in the graph above is a path of length 2.

Proposition: If $u_0\mathrm{-} u_1\mathrm{-} \ldots\mathrm{-} u_{n-1}\mathrm{-} u_{n}$ is a walk of length $n\geq3$ such that $u_0\neq u_n$, then there exist vertices $v_1, \ldots,v_m$ such that $u_0\mathrm{-} v_1\mathrm{-} \ldots\mathrm{-} v_m\mathrm{-} u_{n}$ is a path of length at most $n$. (Where there is a walk, there is a path that is not longer.)

Stronger Proposition: If $u_0\mathrm{-} u_1\mathrm{-} \ldots\mathrm{-} u_{n-1}\mathrm{-} u_{n}$ is a walk of length $n\geq3$ such that $u_0\neq u_n$, then there exist vertices $v_1, \ldots,v_m$ such that $u_0\mathrm{-} v_1\mathrm{-} \ldots\mathrm{-} v_m\mathrm{-} u_{n}$ is a path whose sequence of nodes and edges is a subsequence of the sequence of nodes and edges of $u_0\mathrm{-} u_1\mathrm{-} \ldots\mathrm{-} u_{n-1}\mathrm{-} u_{n}$.
Here, “subsequence” preserves order, but it does not necessarily consist of consecutive elements.

Connected Components

Connectivity

Two vertices $u$ and $v$ of a graph $G=(V,E)$ are said to be connected, notation $u\mathrm{-}\ldots\mathrm{-}v$, if there exists some walk with endpoints $u$ and $v$. We call $\mathrm{-}\ldots\mathrm{-}$ the connectivity relation.
Connectivity is an equivalence relation, which means that connectivity is reflexive, symmetric and transitive.

Connected Components

A connected component of a graph $G = (V,E)$ is a set of vertices $C\subseteq V$ such that:

  • any two vertices in $C$ are connected, and
  • there is no strictly bigger set of vertices $C \subsetneq C’ \subseteq V$ such that any two vertices in $C’$ are connected.
    We say that $C$ is a maximally connected set of vertices of $G$.

In this graph we have two connected components:$\{1,2,3,4\}$ and $\{5,6,7\}$.

Partition

Clearly, every vertex is in some connected components, at worst by itself. Proposition: Any two distinct connected components are disjoint.
The connected components form a partition of the vertices.

Connected graphs

A graph in which any two vertices are connected is called connected, other wise it is called disconnected.
A connected graph has exactly one connected component. A disconnected graph has tow or more connected components.
Complete graphs, $K_n$, path graphs, $P_n$, and cycle graphs, $C_n$, are all connected.
In edgeless graphs, each vertex forms a separate connected component. Thus, edgeless graphs with two or more vertices are disconnected, while 1-vertex graphs are connected.
The $m\times n$ grid graphs are connected.

Counting Connected Components

Consider a graph $G = (V,E)$ and denote by $CC$ the set of connected components of $G$. Shorthand: $cc$ for “connected component.”
Proposition: max($|V| - |E|$, 1) $\leq|C|\leq|V|$.
Proposition: In any graph $G = (V,E)$ we have $|E|\geq|V|-|CC|$.
Proposition: $|E| \leq \binom{|V|}{2}$.
Corollary: Every connected graph with $n$ vertices has $n-1$ or more edges.



FOOTNOTES

All the contents are based on the course materials provided by Dr. Clayton Greenberg.

entry.title: The Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic
entry.content:
Quick Guide

  1. The Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic(FTA)
  2. Proof example by contradiction with FTA

The Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic(FTA)

Given any integer $n>1$, there exists a positive integer $k$, distinct prime numbers $p_1,p_2,\ldots,p_k$, and positive integers $e_1,e_2,\ldots,e_k$ such that

$n = p_{1}^{e_1}p_{2}^{e_2}p_{3}^{e_3}\ldots p_{k}^{e_k}$

and any other expression of $n$ as a product of powers of primes is identical to this except, perhaps, for the order in which the factors are written.

Proof example by contradiction with FTA

Prove that $\sqrt{22}$ is irrational.

Proof : Contradiction.
Assume that $\sqrt{22}$ is rational. Then $\sqrt{22}$ can be expressed as a fraction $\sqrt{22} = \frac{p}{q}$ with $p \in \mathbb{Z}$ and $q \in \mathbb{Z^+}$.
Then

$22~=~\frac{p^2}{q^2}$
$p^2~=~22q^2$

From the second equation it follows that $p^2~ =~ 2 \times 11q^2$.

According to $\textbf{The Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic(FTA)}$, we have that any positive integer can be expressed as

$\prod^{n}_{i=1} m_i^{e_i}$

where $m_i$ is prime number and $e_i \in \mathbb{Z^+}$.

We can assume for $p^2$, since it has a power of 2, that all the $e_i$ for $p^2$ should be even. The same can be applied to $q^2$ that all the $e_i$ for $q^2$ should be even. So that in the expression for $2 \times 11q^2$, the power for prime number 2 should be odd and the power for prime number 11 should be odd. This is a contradiction to the statement that all the $e_i$ for $p^2$ should be even. So that $\sqrt{22}$ is not rational, naming that $\sqrt{22}$ irrational.
$Q.E.D$

FOOTNOTES

All the contents are based on the course materials provided by Dr. Clayton Greenberg.

entry.title: Graph Theorem 0 - Proof Patterns
entry.content:
Graphs are often too large to interpret manually, so we use contrapositive proofs, contradiction proofs, and induction proofs to reason about arbitrary graphs. The Fibonacci numbers will also be covered as bonus.

Quick Guide

  1. Converse and Contrapositive
  2. Contradiction
  3. Ordinary Induction
  4. Strong Induction
  5. Recurrence

Converse and Contrapositive

Converse

The converse of “if $p$ the $q$” is “if $q$ then $p$”.
In logic notation: the converse of $p \Rightarrow q$ is $q \Rightarrow p$.
Generally, the converse is not logically equivalent to the original implication.

Contrapositive

The contrapositive of “if $p$ the $q$” is “if (not $q$) then (not $p$)”.
In logic notation: the contrapositive of $p \Rightarrow q$ is $\neg q \Rightarrow \neg p$.
Note that the contrapositive is logically equivalent to the original implication, which leads to a proof pattern that instead of the implication, prove its contrapositive.

Tips: the contrapositive doesn’t change the quantifiers like $\forall$ and $\exists$. For example, the contrapositive for

"for any integers $x,y$, if $xy$ is even then $x$ is even or $y$ is even"


is

"for any integers $x,y$, if $x$ is odd and $y$ is odd then $xy$ is odd".


Contradiction

A statement of the form “$P$ and (not $P$)” is called a contradiction. It is always false.
Here a new proof pattern is introduced that to prove “$P$” we can instead prove “if (not $P$) then $C$”, where $C$ stands for a statement that is a contradiction. This proof pattern can be justified by the logical equivalence that $p \equiv \neg p \Rightarrow F$.
Also, if we want to prove “if $P$ then $Q$” we can instead prove “if $P$ and (not $Q$) then $C$”, which is another proof pattern. This proof pattern is justified by the logical equivalence that $p \Rightarrow q \equiv p \wedge \neg q \Rightarrow F$. A proof example is given in note The Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic
Note that any proof by contrapositive can be converted into a proof by contradiction.

Ordinary Induction

Induction is a useful proof pattern for statements in the form: “for all nature numbers $n$ we have $P(n)$”, where $P(n)$ is a predicate whose truth depends on $n$. In logical notation: $\forall n \in \mathbb{N}\ P(n)$.

Proof Pattern of Ordinary Induction

Let $P(n)$ be a predicate whose truth depends on $n$.
Proof pattern:
(Base Case) Check that $P(0)$ holds true.
(Induction Step) Let $k$ be an arbitrary natural number. Assume $\textbf{P(k)}.$ Using that derive $P(k+1)$.
Conclude $\forall n \in \mathbb{N} \ P(n)$.

The $P(k)$ inside the box in the induction step is called the Induction Hypothesis(IH). The IH must be stated inside the induction step because it refers to $k$.
In logical notation the induction step is $\forall k \in \mathbb{N}\ \ P(k) \Rightarrow P(k+1)$.

There is also a variant proof pattern for ordinary induction:
Let $n_0$ be a natural number and let $P(n)$ be a predicate that is well defined for all natural numbers $n\geq n_0$.
Proof pattern:
(Base Case) Check that $P(n_0)$ holds true.
(Induction Step) Let $k\geq n_0$ be an arbitrary natural number. Assume $\textbf{P(k)}.$ Using that derive $P(k+1)$.
Conclude $\forall n \geq n_0 \ P(n)$.
Induction is a powerful proof method in graph theorem. By doing induction on vertices or edges, problems can be solved.

Strong Induction

Let $n_0$ be a natural number and let $P(n)$ be a predicate that is well defined for all natural numbers $n\geq n_0$.
Proof pattern:
(Base Case) Drive/infer $P(n_0)$.
(Induction Step) Let $k \in \mathbb{N}$ such that $k \geq n_0$. Assume $P(n_0)$ and $\ldots$ and $P(k)$. Using that derive $P(k+1)$.
Conclude $\forall n \geq n_0 \ P(n)$.
The IH $P(n_0)$ and $\ldots$ and $P(k)$ is stronger than $P(k)$. But strong induction is mathematically equivalent to the ordinary induction.

Recurrence

The Fibonacci recurrence is given by

  • $F_0 = 0$
  • $F_1 = 1$
  • $F_n = F_{n-1} + F_{n-2} \ (n\geq 2)$

The Fibonacci recurrence can be solve with $F_n = \frac{(\psi ^n -\ \phi ^n)}{\sqrt{5}}$, where $\psi > \phi$ are the two roots of the equation $x^2 - x - 1 = 0$.
$\psi = \frac{(1+ \sqrt{5})}{2}$ is known as the Golden Ratio and $\phi = \frac{(1- \sqrt{5})}{2}$.

Some useful equations based on Fibonacci numbers
$F_{n-1} \cdot F_{n+1} - F_{n}^2 = (-1)^n$

$\sum_{i=0}^{n}i\cdot F_{2i} = (n+1)F_{2n+1}-F_{2n+2}$

$\sum_{i=0}^{n}F_i^2\cdot F_{i+1}=\frac{1}{2}F_{n+2}F_{n+1}F_{n}$

Next: Graph Theorem 1 - Introduction to Graphs

FOOTNOTES

All the contents are based on the course materials provided by Dr. Clayton Greenberg.
entry.summary: Graphs are often too large to interpret manually, so we use contrapositive proofs, contradiction proofs, and induction proofs to reason about arbitrary graphs. The Fibonacci numbers will also be covered as bonus.

entry.title: CloClé - The Summary
entry.content:
This is the final poster for our CloClé clothes caring machine.



During the pandemic period that might last longer than people could imagine, the demand for convenient and effective ways to sterilize clothes is growing, which is the inspiration for Cloclé. However, Cloclé is more than just simple clothes sanitizer. It is a cost-effective multifunction clothes caring machine that can disinfect, dry, iron, and incense garment, which is easily monitored and controlled via App on mobile phones. The name of product is combined with abbreviations of clothes, clean and clear to show the function that clothes will be clean and clear from dust and viruses after use. The function is further proved by the logo, which is ancient seal character of the word “Clothes”.

Quick Guide

  1. Key Customer Needs
  2. Patentability Assessment
  3. Design for Environment
  4. Next Step to Pursue the Product as a Business

Key Customer Needs

At the beginning of 2020, rarely can people imagine how profoundly COVID-19, which seemed trivial at that time, would change everyone’s lives in the days that followed. Till now nearly 10 million people have been diagnosed and results in nearly half a million deaths. World Health Organization has emphasized the importance on frequent hand washing/sanitizing and clothes disinfecting. In current pandemic and predicted second wave in the coming autumn and winter, the need for energy-efficient, cost-effective and effective clothing disinfection methods cannot be ignored. Based on this need, we conducted a market survey and found that 85% of the respondents were very interested in this kind of product. People also put forward many worthy demands, such as multi-function, easy to move and easy to operate. These demands inspired us to design beyond a simple clothes sanitizer. We hope that Cloclé can promote the habit of drying clothes, especially in developing countries, so as to expand the market of clothes dryers and clothes care machines. The purpose of Cloclé is to lay a solid foundation for our subsequent products.

Patentability Assessment

Cloclé is comprised of a leakproof side shell, a rigid clothes hanger, a central supporting column, a rigid base, a steam generator, a hot air generator, a water tank, few hot steam/air circulation systems, a rotating system, and corresponding signal transmission and control system. After hanging clothes, the side rails to fix leakproof side shell lock automatically. Then the machine starts the clothes caring program. Air circulation systems spray hot steam or hot air into the cavity and draw them back. The hot steam at about 60℃ realizes the function of disinfection and ironing. And the hot air realizes the function of drying. By adding essential oil into the water tank, the incense function is also realized. The circulation systems rotate at the speed of 10 rpm to ensure the uniformity of disinfection. The temperature, humidity, time and other data of the whole machine are transmitted to the mobile phone via Bluetooth and can be controlled through the mobile phone App by choosing different recipe for clothing care. When the internal pressure or the temperature is too high, the machine will alarm or even stop automatically.


By searching relevant patents, we believe that Cloclé is different from existing patents and it is novel enough to get a patent. Specific claims include designs for multifunction, safety protection mechanism, energy conservation, better user experience, etc.

Design for Environment

We attach great importance to the environmental performance of Cloclé so that sustainability assessment iterations are conducted during the whole design process. We chose various recycled materials such as PP, PEVA, and Aluminum to cut ecological damage. We also adopted modular design concept and tried to use a single type of material in the same module as far as possible. Besides, we flexibly design transportation modes according to distribution distance to reduce environmental impacts.

The prototype for CloClé.


Next Step to Pursue the Product as a Business

In order to cut costs, we will eliminate the retail process and sell products through the recently rapidly developing e-business, which also saves operating costs for cooperating with retailers, planning supply chain and so on. We plan to reduce production costs and margins, focusing on market development and demand cultivation rather than short-term profits. There are mainly two types of competitors in current market. The first type is the wardrobe clothes care machine which has comprehensive functions and great effects. But these machines are too expensive and take up large family space, not suitable for ordinary customers that Cloclé aimed at. The other type is the hanging steam sterilizer, which is cheap and simple. But these machines usually require manual operation and the function is limited. Therefore, we believe that Cloclé has a broad potential market. Current epidemic situation also greatly facilitates the product promotion. We plan to sell 2 million sets of products in the coming 10 years and earn an NPV of around 28.7 million dollars. According to the purpose of market development and demand cultivation, our focus will mainly be on advertising and propagating. We intend to use both traditional and new media to publicize the necessity of clothes disinfection and clothing care. At the same time, we will pay close attention to the feedback from users and correspondingly iterate the products to improve the user experience. When the market is mature, we will also release follow-up products to expand and refine the market of clothes disinfection and care and further profit from it.
